catalog.dc:comment: v0.2.0 v0.1.0 01/09/2024 Initial release of catalog. Developer Keith Lines, Data Science department, NPL (UK).
catalog.title: Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan: Version 0.2.0
catalog.help: This catalog is for developing plans that document quality requirements for developing software for mathematics and statistics in metrology. It is based on the Quality Assurance Tools developed by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics.

page.title: Introduction
page.help:
The following questionnaire creates a software quality assurance plan. This plan supports documenting the people, procedures and activities performed to fulfil predefined quality objectives during the development and maintenance of software within the metrology community and wider scientific domains, in which quality and trustworthiness are essential. The aim is to supplement, not replace, software development procedures within Mathmet partner organisations. It is assumed that an iterative development lifecycle will be used. However, the quality requirements listed in the plan could be met using other approaches, for example waterfall or agile. Further details of the approach taken in this plan are provided in the corresponding publication by Mathmet.

Glossary

TermDefinitionSource
Customer Person or organization that could or does receive a product or a service that is intended for or required by this person or organization. A customer can be internal or external to the organization. ISO 9000:2015
Computational aim Document providing a clear, complete and unambiguous statement of a mathematical calculation. ISO 9000:2015
Development team Team that develops or maintains software. ISO/IEC/IEEE 24765:2017
Quality The degree to which a set of inherent characteristics of an object fulfils requirements. ISO 9000:2015
Release Put into use in providing a service, delivered to a customer or used to generate output for inclusion in work to be delivered to a customer (e.g. project deliverables, papers, reports etc.). N/A
Requirement Need or expectation that is stated, generally implied or obligatory. ISO 9000:2015
Requirements traceability Discernible association between a requirement and related requirements, implementations, and verifications. ISO/IEC/IEEE 24765:2017
Risk analysis Systematic use of available information to identify hazards and to estimate the risk. ISO/IEC Guide 51:2014
Software Shall refer to any software type. N/A
Software type One of the following: spreadsheets, databases, macros, scripts, programs and web applications. N/A
Software integrity level (SWIL) A risk assessment metric that accounts for complexity and criticality levels. A value that helps quantify the risk associated with the software. A SWIL is a number between 1 and 4, where 1 indicates the lowest level of risk and 4 the highest (typically safety-critical). Section 3. Software Integrity Level
Trustworthy A software or other product which appropriately addresses safety, reliability, availability, resilience and security issues.

NOTE: The reference refers to these issues as the five facets of trustworthiness.		 BS 10754-1:2018
Uncertainty budget Statement of a measurement uncertainty, of the components of that measurement uncertainty, and of their calculation and combination. International Vocabulary of Metrology (VIM)
Validation Confirmation, through the provision of objective evidence, that the requirements for a specific intended use or application have been fulfilled.

NOTE: For the Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan, validation focuses on user requirements (see section 4).		 ISO 9000:2015
Verification Confirmation, through the provision of objective evidence, that specified requirements have been fulfilled.

NOTE: For the Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan, verification focuses on functional requirements (see section 5).		 ISO 9000:2015


For further definitions, unless stated otherwise, this document refers to BS ISO/IEC/IEEE 24765:2017 Systems and software engineering — Vocabulary for definitions of software engineering terms and the International Vocabulary of Metrology (VIM) for definitions of terms from metrology.

question.help: Enter an unambiguous name for the software. Naming conventions will be determined by the developer(s)' organisation(s) and any project(s) for which the software is being developed.

attribute.dc:comment: Short ID for a dataset, used as questionset attribute for dataset related questionsets.

question.help:
Describe, as briefly as possible the intended tasks the software will perform, users and equipment (for example, hardware). Also include any other relevant information (for example, programming languages or operating systems).

These subjects will be covered in more detail in the documentation to be developed. But an initial description, comparable to an abstract for a document, will help determine the Software Integrity Level (SWIL) in section 3.

Enter the name(s) and, if required, role(s) and contact details of the development team. Team members may have different roles: e.g., technical lead, programmer(s), tester(s). For smaller teams, a team might have a single member, members may have multiple roles.

attribute.dc:comment: Created by Keith Lines, NPL UK for Mathmet catalogs. 20/11/2024

question.help:
The individual or organisation who accepts delivery of the software or output generated by the software (for example, calibration certificates). It may not be easy to determine who the customer is. However, the matter is worth considering because it could, for example, help determine the SWIL.

In general, it is preferable to list the customer as a person rather than a generic term such as an organisation name. More specifically, this person might be:
  • A staff member in an organisation developing the software, acting as a proxy for an external organisation (for example, a funding body or an industrial client).
  • Someone holding responsibility for funding the work for which this software is being developed.
  • There may not be a direct customer for the software itself, but someone will be the customer for the output generated by the software.

attribute.dc:comment: Created by Keith Lines, NPL UK for Mathmet catalogs. 20/11/2024

question.dc:comment: Software location can, for example, contain a hyperlink to a Git repository, a SharePoint folder, or a networked drive. It is important that the software is located somewhere it can be found by others than its original author(s).
question.help:
Provide the location where the software, including source code, and documentation is stored. For example, provide a hyperlink to a Git repository, a shared folder or a networked drive.

It is important that the source code and documentation is not stored somewhere it can only be found by the original developer(s). Finding the correct versions of the source code and documentation could be a significant challenge after these developers have left the organisation. Other matters to consider regarding location are listed in section 2.2 of this Mathmet paper.
question.text: Q1.5 Location of Software and Documentation *

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

page.title: 2 Version Control of Plan
page.help: This section of the software quality assurance plan concerns the plan itself, not the software and not the RDMO catalog.

question.help: Select the status. An initial version of the plan should have status Draft. Before being used, the plan should be reviewed by the development team and the status changed to Issued.
Enter the version number of this plan. The version numbering convention used will be determined by the developer(s)' organisation(s) and any project(s) for which the software is being developed.
Select the date on which this version of the plan was completed.
Enter the name(s), and contact details if required, of the plan’s author(s). Either enter all names or the name(s) of selected contact person(s), as considered appropriate.

attribute.dc:comment: Data managers for Mathmet Data Quality.

question.help: Enter details of the change(s) in this version of the plan. For the first version of this plan enter initial version.

attribute.dc:comment: Inserted by National Physical Laboratory UK for Mathmet templates. Keith Lines 21/11/2024
Inserted by National Physical Laboratory UK for Mathmet templates. Keith Lines 21/11/2024

page.title: 3 Software Integrity Level
page.help:
A risk analysis results in the calculation of a Software Integrity Level (SWIL). The SWIL is a numeric value, between 1 and 4, that determines the quality requirements for the software. Examples are provided in Table 1.
Table 1: Software Integrity Level (SWIL) and examples.
CodeDescriptive nameExample
SWIL 1Not critical Software developed as a prototype / proof of concept. For example, for testing suitability of new hardware for a perspective measurement service.
SWIL 2Significant Software generating results for research purposes. A typical risk that could occur is (at worst)is the retraction of a publication.
SWIL 3Substantial Software generating results for a measurement service, such as calibration or conformity assessment.
SWIL 4Life critical Software that forms part of an avionics system.


The SWIL is calculated using two other parameters, criticality of usage and complexity of software, which also take values between 1 and 4. The selection of values for these parameters is indicative and to some extent subjective. However, factors such as the following could help determine these values and should be noted:
  • Is the software being developed either by, or in close collaboration with, expert mathematicians or statisticians or scientists?
  • Is it anticipated that the software will consist of a large number of modules, or call a large number of libraries?
  • Is the software intended to be used by technically knowledge operators?

NOTE: The acronym SWIL was adopted, rather than SIL, because of a clash of terminology with the IEC 61508 series of standards. In these standards SIL stands for Safety Integrity Level, a term which focuses on functional safety and concerns hardware as well as software.

question.help:
Evaluate the criticality of usage (CU) of the software, i.e. the consequences of customers using software of inappropriate quality particularly on business/reputation.

Table 2: Criticality of usage.
CodeDescriptive nameExample
CU 1Not critical
  • No danger of loss of income or reputation.
  • Short life, will not require maintenance in future.
CU 2Significant
  • Potential for loss of income or reputation.
CU 3Substantial
  • Likely to lead to loss of income or reputation.
CU 4Life critical
  • May result in personal injury, loss of life or damage to the environment.

Evaluate the anticipated complexity of the software. Software complexity (CP) can be defined considering one or more of: (a) the complexity of the mathematics implemented (b) the anticipated size of the source code, perhaps as lines of code or function points (c) whether control of an external system is involved.

Table 3: Complexity of software.
CodeDescriptive nameExplanation, typical features
CP 1Very simple
  • Elementary functionality, easy to understand.
  • Little or no control of an external system.
  • Simple mathematics
CP 2Simple
  • Simple functionality.
  • Straightforward control of a system.
  • Intermediate mathematics.
CP 3Moderate
  • Large or very large programs.
  • Difficult to modify.
  • Complicated mathematics.
CP 4Complex
  • Extremely complex functionality.
  • Complex feedback systems.
  • Very complicated mathematics.

After risk has been analysed, calculate the SWIL using the following formula: ``` if(CU==1) SWIL=1 else SWIL=max(CU, CP) ``` Also see Table 4. This recommended SWIL can be accepted, or it could be revised by the development team. For example, if inexperienced software developers are involved, the team can decide to increase the SWIL. If the SWIL value is revised, then the project-specific factors that justify increasing or decreasing the recommended SWIL value must be documented.
Table 4: Calculating the Software Integrity Level.
CP 1CP 2CP 3CP 4
CU 1SWIL 1SWIL 1SWIL 1SWIL 1
CU 2SWIL 2SWIL 2SWIL 3SWIL 4
CU 3SWIL 3SWIL 3SWIL 3SWIL 4
CU 4SWIL 4SWIL 4SWIL 4SWIL 4
question.text: Q3.3a Does the calculated SWIL seem suitable? *
question.verbose_name: Does the calculated SWIL seem suitable?

question.help: The calculated SWIL can be accepted. Alternatively, the SWIL could be revised. If the software is determined to be SWIL 4 then seek guidance from safety critical software experts
question.text: Q3.3b Factors that justify increasing or decreasing the SWIL
question.verbose_name: Factors that justify increasing or decreasing the SWIL

condition.dc:comment: Does the value of software integrity level (SWIL) calculated from criticality and complexity need to be modified? NOTE: The catalog uses the equivalent concept of the data integrity level (DIL) from the Mathmet data quality plan template.

question.help: The reviewed SWIL can also be the same value as the originally calculated SWIL.
Note any further reasons for selection of CU, CP and therefore SWIL values.

page.title: 4 User Requirements
page.help:
This section of the plan lists the quality requirements, determined by either the reviewed SWIL or recommended SWIL (if reviewed SWIL not entered).
  • Fill in the relevant sections indicating actions taken to meet requirements. For example, state location where documents held.
  • Mathematics must be specified clearly and unambiguously.
User requirements are a statement of what is required from the software, not how it is going to meet these requirements.

question.help:
Enter a link to the document that contains the user requirements, or to a folder where the documents are held. For smaller pieces of software, it may be possible to enter the requirements directory into the plan. Matters to consider in user requirements, before development begins, include:
  • User friendly GUI
  • Data / statistical analysis
  • Data visualisation and graphics
  • Notifications and alerts
  • Clear documentation for users
question.text: Q4.1 Documentation of user requirements *

page.title: 5 Functional requirements
page.help: In this plan, function does not mean a software module, for example, a MATLAB script, a C function. Instead, it means a task, action, or activity that must be accomplished to achieve a desired outcome.

question.dc:comment: This question is mandatory for selected SWIL.
question.help:
Non-trivial mathematics is highly likely to underpin most of the software developed with the assistance of this plan. A clear, complete and unambiguous statement of the mathematics will allow it to be verified without having to examine any code. It must not be necessary to examine the code of even the shortest script to determine the mathematics implemented.

An online database of documents called computational aims, developed as part of the EURAMET Traceability for computationally intensive metrology (TraCIM) project, provides an example of specifying mathematical calculations.

Other matters to consider in functional requirements, before development begins, include report generation and input/output data formats. For software that will form part of a calibration system also consider:
  • Calculations for the calibration of a measuring instrument
  • Determination of uncertainty budgets
  • Easy upload of measurement and calibration data
  • Recording of calculation results
  • Analysis of trends on historical data (measuring instruments, standards and calibrations items)
  • Notifications of acceptance criteria and measurement requirements
  • Publication of calibration certificates
question.text: Q5.1 Documentation of functional requirements *

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

See definition of requirements traceability in the glossary at the start of this document.

page.title: 6 Design
page.help:
For much of the software developed with the assistance of this plan, a simple block diagram may well be sufficient for both informal and well-structured documented design. For example, software that consists of a few MATLAB scripts could have its design documented with a block diagram illustrating which script calls which script and which is the main script.

For other software, particularly SWIL 3 or 4 software, formal design languages such as the Unified Modelling Language (UML) or the Systems Modelling Language (SysML).

Also consider the provenance of packages and libraries. For example, a richly featured, but new and experimental, library may be appropriate for SWIL 1 or 2 software but not SWIL 3 or 4. There are often no “right” or “wrong” answers, just decisions to made, documented and reviewed. Other matters to consider include:
  • Modular structure
  • Ease of maintenance
  • Ability to incorporate new functionality

question.help: Enter link(s) to document(s) providing the software design.

question.help:
Variables that identify the software name, version and date of release are important for even the smallest script. It is important the user is left in no doubt as to the name and version number of the software being run.
Such information is key to traceability of output, as will be noted in delivery, use and maintenance.

page.title: 10 Delivery, Use and Maintenance
page.help: This section covers matters that help the software be useable in the longer term. Even smaller pieces of software could benefit, as it can aid reproducibility and reusability. NOTE: Maintenance is defined as correct bugs, improve performance, improve other attributes (e.g. user interface layout) or adapt to a changed environment (for example, an operating system upgrade, a new version of MATLAB, MS-Office, Python etc.).

question.help: Enter details of how version control will be achieved, for example using a tool such as Git or Subversion. For very simple pieces of software an appropriate file or folder naming convention may be sufficient.
question.text: Q10.1 Version control on release *

question.help: Enter details of how version control will be achieved, for example using a tool such as Git or Subversion. For very simple pieces of software an appropriate file or folder naming convention may be sufficient.
As above, expect maintain version control before software is released.
question.text: Q10.2 Version control before release *

attribute.dc:comment: introduced by the Max Planck Digital Library to implement the Software Management Plan

question.help: As above, expect maintain version control before software is released.

Enter details of how enhancement requests and bug reports will be logged and tracked. For example, Git provides features for issue tracker. In some instances, as considered appropriate by the development team, email trails (copied to a project folder, not stored within the email system itself) may be appropriate for this purpose.
question.text: Q10.3 Enhancement requests / bug tracking / error logging *
question.verbose_name: Enhancement requests / bug tracking / error logging

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

question.text: Q10.3 Enhancement requests / bug tracking / error logging
question.verbose_name: Enhancement requests / bug tracking / error logging

question.help:
Enter details of how the outputs generated by the software, for example results to be presented in customer certificates or research papers, can be traced to the name and version of the software that generated them. Other information, such as date and time of execution, identifier of operator/user and location of raw data may also be necessary.
Reproducibility of results can be made easier by making such data available.

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

Enter details of how the outputs generated by the software, for example results to be presented in customer certificates or research papers, can be traced to the name and version of the software that generated them. Other information, such as date and time of execution, identifier of operator/user and location of raw data may also be necessary.
Reproducibility of results can be made easier by making such data available.

Explain how user documentation will be provided. For example, a document could be written covering matters such as the following: * Program identifier/name and version number * Install/uninstall guide * Overview of physics / mathematics etc. * Instructions for operation * How to report enhancement requests / bugs

Explain how user documentation will be provided. For example, a document could be written covering matters such as the following: * Program identifier/name and version number * Install/uninstall guide * Overview of physics / mathematics etc. * Instructions for operation * How to report enhancement requests / bugs

section.dc:comment:
• This section provides details such as the platform, for example, operating system and hardware, on which the software will run. Any specific requirements for the software, for example minimum hardware requirements, could also be listed in this section.
  • One possible difficulty could be presented by Responsibilities for testing. As discussed in section 1, who the customer is may not necessarily be easy to determine.
• Selecting Mathematical Area(s) and Metrology Area(s) will be helpful when considering how the software should be verified and validated. Such information is also useful documentation.
section.title: Other Information

page.title: 11 Platform etc.
page.help: This section contains all information concerning the practical development of the software. It documents technical details on programming and release management, strategical and security-related decisions and responsibilities.

question.help: Enter details of hardware device and/or associated operating system, or virtual environment, on which software can be installed or run. The software could also run on a cloud platform. See definitions of platform and platform as a service (PaaS) in reference [5] for further details.
Select appropriate value. See definition of software type in the glossary at the start of this document for further details.

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

optionset.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

question.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.
question.help: Enter names of programming language(s) that will be used. For example, C, C#, Fortran, LabVIEW, MATLAB, Python etc.

attribute.dc:comment: introduced by the Max Planck Digital Library to implement the Software Management Plan
introduced by the Max Planck Digital Library to implement the Software Management Plan

question.help: Enter details of how files will be backed up. Note that this matter is not same as version control. Reference [5] describes backup as “system, component, file, procedure, or person available to replace or help restore a primary item in the event of a failure or externally caused disaster”.
See definition of release in the glossary at the start of this document. A list of instructions on how to release the software, such as a checklist, can help avoid errors in releasing the software.

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

question.help: Enter details of how components of the software be managed, both hardware and software. E.g., if external libraries are required how will user know which versions?

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

question.help: If necessary, provide further outline of how issues described in section 10 will be implemented.

attribute.dc:comment: Included by the European Metrology Network for Mathematics and Statistics (Mathmet) for Mathmet Software Quality Assurance Plan.

page.title: 13 Other Information: Mathematical area(s) and Metrology area(s)
page.verbose_name: 13 Other Information: Mathematical area(s) and Metrology area(s)

question.help: Selecting Mathematical Area(s) and Metrology Area(s) will be helpful when considering how the software should be verified and validated. The list of mathematical areas was determined by the EURAMET [“Traceability for computationally intensive metrology” (TraCIM)](https://www.tracim.eu/2123.html) project.
The list of metrology areas is derived from the list of [EURAMET Technical Committees](https://www.euramet.org/technical-committees).

option.text: QM: Amount of substance: metrology in chemistry
option.view_text: QM: Amount of substance: metrology in chemistry
